entry.title: How to start The War Within campaign quest in WoW
entry.summary:
With the start of every new expansion in World of Warcraft, a breadcrumb quest points you in the direction of the new content, and The War Within is no different. You will need to complete the first breadcrumb quest to head to the new area in which the expansion takes place. Here is how to start The War Within campaign quest in WoW.
Screenshot by Destructoid
How to start The War Within quest in WoW
As long as you are a Level 70 character in World of Warcraft, simply logging in will cause the breadcrumb quest, properly titled The War Within to pop up. If you open your Quest Log, you should see the quest at the top under your Campaign quests.
Some players who were logged in to World of Warcraft at the time that The War Within quest went active indicated that they didn't automatically receive the breadcrumb popup notification for the new expansion quest. If you don't automatically receive The War Within quest in WoW, try simply logging out, completely closing World of Warcraft, and then relaunching and logging back in.
Re-logging in seems to fix the bug that causes The War Within campaign quest to not automatically start.
How to complete The War Within quest and reach Isle of Dorn
For the first The War Within quest, you need to head to the sword that's embedded in Azeroth located in Sillithus. It's the same place you started your journey in the Battle for Azeroth expansion. Check your inventory for a scroll that will automatically teleport you to where the quest starts. Head under the sword and speak with Magni to continue The War Within quest and progress through the quest objectives.
After finishing this initial quest, you will head to Dalaran to complete the introduction to The War Within. Upon completing this introduction questline you will end up at The Isle of Dorn and continue your journey in WoW The War Within.

entry.title: Minecraft: How many bookshelves are needed for level 30 enchantments?
entry.summary:
Embarking on your Minecraft upgrade journey begins with the creation of an enchanting table setup, a pivotal step that opens the door to the best tools. While acquiring low to mid-range gear is straightforward, reaching the highest tier necessitates a specific building arrangement. We're here to explain how many bookshelves you need for the Level 30 enchantment in Minecraft.
How many bookshelves do you use for level 30 enchantments in Minecraft?
You can unlock Level 30 enhancements in Minecraft by placing 15 bookshelves within a one-block radius of the table. The build must also be on a two-block level, as any shelves placed on the third level will not count towards it. To give you an example, the setup on the left won't work (bookshelves are on the third block), but the one on the right checks out:
Image by Destructoid
The bookshelves basically have to be as close to the enchanting table as possible. Nevertheless, you can still place them one block away to give you room. If you need some ideas on how to build it, you can check out our guide on the best enchanting table setups.
Although the build helps set the stage for the enhancement, you'll still need to take a few more steps to get better materials. The maximum tier requires three lapis lazuli and a Level 30 experience rank. Go deep into the mines to acquire the lapis lazuli, which can also help you gain XP for your levels.
To earn more XP in Minecraft, look for Monster Spawners in the mines and defeat hordes of enemies. It'll take some time to reach the higher ranks, so keep mining and fighting to farm a ton of experience points.
Once you've tackled the requirements, place your desired tool in the enchanting table. You'll gain unique buffs like the highly durable Unbreaking III or the damaging Smite V. However, enchantments are completely randomized, so it all depends on the luck of the draw.

entry.title: What are Melee Backstab Kills in Modern Warfare 3?
entry.summary:
The deadly Backstab Kills have appeared in many objectives, including Weekly Challenges and weapon unlocks. But, since the elimination doesn't have a description, it can be confusing to understand. If you want to know what to do, we'll explain what Melee Backstab Kills are in Modern Warfare 3.
MW3 Melee Backstab Kills, explained
Melee Backstab Kills are eliminations that must be performed behind an enemy Operator using a Melee-based weapon. Regular guns won't work with this tactic; therefore, you must use tools like Karambit, Gutter Knife, or Sledgehammer.
Performing the Melee Backstab Kills without the proper preparations will be challenging. To help you through this, use Tactical Equipment such as Stun and Smoke Grenades. Cast out this equipment in battle and try to sneak up behind the enemy while they're in a vulnerable state.
Screenshot by Destructoid
To be extra sly, utilize Covert Sneakers or Dead Silence to remove an Operator's footstep sounds. This will make it easier for you to sneak up on the enemy without being detected. You can also equip Ghost T/V Camo to get you off UAVs, Heartbeat Sensors, and enemy radar sources. Without these items, you'll be pretty easy to spot, as running can get the attention of enemy Operators.
Use small maps to earn the Melee Backstab Kills in Modern Warfare 3 quickly. I like going into Shipment for this since everyone tends to get caught in the chaos from its compact size. Then, when the opponent is preoccupied with someone else, you can sneak your way in for the elimination.
Completing this task earns you various rewards, depending on the season. For example, Season 5 Reloaded's Spear requires players to get three Melee Backstab or Special Zombie Kills. It also comes up a lot in Weekly Challenges, so keep it in mind for future references. And, if you're confused about any more Call of Duty terms, be sure to check out our guides on Clean and Gun-Butt Kills.

entry.title: After three hours of Bloober's Silent Hill 2, it's unclear who is remaking who
entry.summary:
Silent Hill has a messy, up-is-down relationship with time and history, so let's go about this hands-on with the Silent Hill 2 Remake in a messy, up-is-down way. Developed well over two decades ago, the original Silent Hill 2 is the magnum opus of Polish horror stalwarts Bloober Team. Running on then-innovative "Unreal Engine 5" technology created by Jazz Jackrabbit publishers Epic MegaGames, it's a wonderful abyss of a game that remains perfectly playable today, given a certain amount of tolerance for the quirks of the era. It begins with your character, James Sunderland, descending from the road towards the eponymous Midwestern nowhere-town. Like many games of the period, Silent Hill 2 uses a third-person, over-the-shoulder manual camera, which allows you to glance fearfully up at the monstrous pine trees that fringe the path - each rising from a bulging tide of fog that menaces with the suggestion of approaching figures. There is moisture everywhere, gushing from drain pipes and dribbling down concrete barriers. As you amble into the murk, deathly chords and groaning, unmechanical motifs reverberate from somewhere deep underground.

entry.title: The Dead Rising remaster no longer gives you points for "Erotica" creepshots because it's not "required" or "appropriate"
entry.summary: Aside from being a game where you run around a shopping mall murdering the living dead, the original Dead Rising from 2006 is a clownish satire of sleazy tabloid photojournalism. It expresses this by way of its scoring system, where you earn "Prestige points" for snapping pictures that fit one of five categories: "Brutal" scenes of characters being slain; moments of "Horror", such as the spectacle of an approaching horde; comical "Outtakes", like characters caught in bizarre poses; moments of "Drama", such as people reacting to discoveries; and "Erotic" photos of women alive or undead, which range from snaps of exposed underwear to close-ups of cleavage. The Erotica tag has, however, been chopped from the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster, in what Capcom gingerly suggest isn't "a response to a changing cultural climate", but expressive of the view that earning points from such photos is not "an appropriate reward for survival and not a skill required of a journalist trying to stay alive".
